awd_titl_txt: Autophagy-dependent and -independent mechanisms of RNA transport to the vacuole and their role in rRNA turnover and cellular homeostasis
awd_abstract_narration:
The pathways by which plant cells recycle their constituents are critical for growth and environmental stress tolerance, yet our knowledge of these pathways is very limited. This project will address these limitations by identifying the mechanisms by which cellular components are recycled once they are damaged or no longer needed. A better understanding of these pathways will allow the development of crops and other plants with an optimized balance between growth and adaptation to stress conditions such as nutrient deficiencies and drought. A number of graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in research during this project, and each year a high school teacher will be involved in the research through an ongoing Research Experiences for Teachers program, potentially impacting large numbers of high school students. Enhancements will be made to an educational computer learning tool on cell biology and it will be introduced into Freshman Biology laboratories. 

Ribosomes are essential and highly abundant components of cells, yet their degradation and recycling pathways are unclear. The goal of this project is to decipher these pathways by analyzing the transport and degradation of ribosomes and ribosomal components within plant vacuoles. A newly discovered pathway for transport of ribosomal RNA will be characterized, using a fluorescent RNA transport assay together with analysis of mutants that are defective in factors required for this pathway. The way in which ribosomes are recognized and selected for degradation, for example by accumulating damage, will be determined biochemically. Metabolome analysis by mass spectrometry will allow the effect of loss of ribosome degradation pathways on cell metabolism and homeostasis to be assessed.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Ribosomes are abundant cellular machines that are essential to all organisms. While much research has focused on how to build ribosomes and the way they work, much less is known about the mechanisms by which their components are recycled once a ribosome is no longer used by the cell.

One of the main constituents of ribosomes is ribosomal RNA (rRNA). In previous work we found that an enzyme localized in the plant vacuole, the ribonuclease RNS2, is required for rRNA degradation in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The function of RNS2 is very important to maintain cellular equilibrium, as plants missing this ribonuclease have elevated autophagy (the cellular process of “self-eating”). The overall objective of this proposal was to understand why recycling of rRNA was necessary for cellular equilibrium, the enzymes used in the vacuole to salvage RNA components, and the mechanisms used by the cell to move ribosomes or rRNA from the cytoplasm, where the carry out their biological functions, to the vacuole, where they are recycled.

Using a combination of pharmacological, genetic and biochemical tools, we were able to identify several routes of rRNA transport into vacuoles, and developed new methods that allowed for identification of some of the components of the transport machinery and its properties. We also described the vacuolar phosphatases that team up with RNS2 to convert RNA into its nucleoside constituents. These nucleosides are then transported to back to the cytoplasm to maintain the balance of nucleotides used for a large number of essential cellular processes. We also found that the level of cytoplasmic nucleotides is sensed by a master regulator, Target of Rapamycin (TOR), that controls allows the cell to switch between growth or stress responses. When rRNA recycling is defective and nucleotide pools are depleted, the TOR pathway causes self-eating as a compensatory mechanism.

These results represent a significant advance in our understanding of the metabolism of rRNA, an essential cellular component in all organisms, and the most abundant class of RNA in the cell, and its connection to primary metabolism and contribution to maintenance of cellular homeostasis. The RNase T2 family of ribonucleases, to which RNS2 belongs, is conserved in all eukaryotes. The mechanism of RNA salvage is conserved in most eukaryotes, from yeast to plants and animals. Thus, although our research is carried out using primarily a plant model system, understanding the molecular events underlying these processes could have a profound impact on human health.

Our project also had a significant educational component. We built the research, communication, and mentoring skills of several graduate students and postdocs to help them advance in their own career paths. We also provided many undergraduate students the opportunity to participate in research and communicate their results to the scientific community. This exposure to the research environment was productive, as most of these students have planned to continue their careers in the life sciences or related professional disciplines. We also hosted high school science teachers as part of a Research Experiences for Teachers program. The teachers received hands-on research a professional team of educators helped them translate their summer experiences into engaging curricula for students and colleagues in their classrooms and schools. Our results were also incorporated in Meta!Blast, a video game designed to help high school and undergraduate students learn cell biological and biochemical concepts.

Given the essential nature of the enzymes and processes that are the subject of our research, we expect that the knowledge generated will ultimately lead to medical advances or agricultural advances that will improve quality of life. Our contribution to the formation of human resources should also have an impact on society, by increasing the number of people with the right set of skills to make informed decisions regarding social issues for which scientific information is available.


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Gustavo Macintosh
